question: Yes, well thank you very much for the ride, sir. You have lovely sheep.

question: Are you cold?

question: Good.
answer: Jack.

question: David.

question: Oh, I don't know. I mean look around. Isn't this a fun place?

question: I'm sorry. Northern England first, Italy later.

question: Do you think she'll meet me in Rome?

question: Debbie is not mediocre and she has one of the great bodies of all time.

question: You're talking about the woman I love.

question: Well, anyway, do you think she'll be there?

question: Rendezvous in Rome starring Jack Goodman and Debbie Klein. The love affair that shocked Europe! See torrid lovemaking at its most explicit! See Jack and Debbie expose their lust in the sacred halls of the Vatican! Never has the screen dared....

question: I have to make love to her. It's very simple. She has no choice really.

question: It is impossible for a body like that to be dull.
answer: We've known Debbie what, since the eighth grade? How many years of foreplay is that?

question: The Slaughtered Lamb?
answer: Of course, The Slaughtered Lamb. Why else would they have a severed fox head on a spear as their symbol?

question: That's a wolf's head.
answer: Of course, The Slaughtered Lamb. Why else would they have a severed wolf's head on a spear as their symbol?

question: That's not a spear. It's a pike.
answer: A severed wolf's head on a pike as their symbol.

question: David, before we go in there I want you to know that - no matter what happens to us - it's your fault.

question: Okay.
answer: Shall we? Hello.

question: Nice to see you.

question: No.

question: We've got spirits and beer. If it's something hot you want, you can have tea.

question: No.
answer: Oh.

question: But I can heat some up for you if you'd like.
answer: Nice looking group.

question: Nice looking group.
answer: Listen, at least it's warm in here.

question: Look at that.

question: It's a five-pointed star.
answer: Maybe the owners are from Texas.

question: Bloody awful if you ask me! Here, Gladys, Tom. Did you hear the one about the crashing plane?

question: You be quiet, woman, and let me speak.

question: All right, laugh then. I shan't tell it.

question: Ask them what the candles are for.

answer: I see. You want me to ask these people if they're burning candles to ward off monsters.

question: Right.
answer: Wrong. The drinkers have gotten the Chess Player to tell the joke as everyone knew he would.

question: Remember the Alamo!
answer: Excuse me, but what's that star on the wall for?

question: You've made me miss.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: That was weird. I guess leaving was the best idea.
answer: I don't know. Now that we're out here and it's three degrees, I'm not so sure I wouldn't rather face a blood- thirsty mob.

question: Well, not quite a blood- thirsty mob.
answer: What do you think was wrong?

question: I have no idea.
answer: Maybe that pentangle was for something supernatural.

question: I see and they were too embarrassed to talk about it, because they felt so silly. There is a flash of lightning that sends a ghostly illuminating sheet of light over the boys' faces. The clap of thunder follows loud and rumbling. Please don't rain. Of course.

question: I'm well aware of how pleasant the weather is in Rome at the present time thank you.
answer: Santa Lucia...Santa Lucia.

question: Did you hear that?
answer: I heard that.

question: What was it?
answer: Could be a lot of things.

question: Yeah?
answer: A coyote.

question: There aren't any coyotes in England.

question: Pecos Bill.
answer: Heathcliffe.

question: Heathcliffe didn't howl.

question: It's a full moon, `beware the moon'. I vote we go back to The Slaughtered Lamb.

question: Shit! David, what is that?

question: Come on, where?

question: Plan?

question: Do you think it's a dog? Oh shit. What is that?
answer: A sheep dog or something. Turn slowly and let's walk away.

question: Nice doggie. Good boy.

question: Walking away, yes, sir. Here we are walking away.

question: Not far enough. Come on.

question: Yeah.

question: Jesus fuck! David! Please help me! Please! David! Shit! Help me! Oh God!

question: Mr. Kessler? Mr. Kessler?
answer: He all right?

question: Yes, I should think. He called out just now.
answer: He's an American, you know. Dr. Hirsch is going to fetch round one of those Embassy fellows to see him.

question: Chart says he's from New York.
answer: I think he's a Jew.

question: Why on earth do you say that?
answer: I looked.

question: Miss Gallagher, surely you must perform some function here at the hospital.
answer: Yes, Doctor.

question: Then get on with it.

question: Can I be of service, Miss Price?

question: Go about your duties.
answer: Yes, Doctor.

question: Oh, Miss Price?

question: What exactly did he call out?

question: That would be Jack Goodman, the boy who was killed.
answer: What happened to them?

question: The police report said an escaped lunatic attacked them. He must have been a very powerful man. Although I really don't see that it is any of your concern, Miss Price.
answer: No, sir. Of course, sir. Good day, Doctor.

question: Hello, David. I am Dr. Hirsch and this is a countryman of yours, Mr. Collins.
answer: Where am I?

question: You're in a hospital in London.
answer: London? Where's Jack? I had a strange dream.

question: I should think so after your recent traumatic experiences.
answer: The guy I was with. Is he all right? How did I get to London?

question: Now, David, I want you to prepare yourself; your friend is dead. David jolts up in bed and shouts.
answer: What? Ow, shit! Jack's dead?

question: What? Ow, shit! Jack's dead?
answer: Mr. Kessler, I am Mr. Collins of the American Embassy here in Grosvenor Square. Both Mr. Goodman's parents and your parents have been notified of your injuries and everything's in order.

question: Everything's in order? What are you talking about?
answer: Mr. Goodman's body has been air-freighted back to New York for burial and your parents have wired funds for your stay in the hospital until you are well enough to fly home.

question: I realize how upsetting this must be for you, Mr. Kessler, but please try to refrain from hysterics.
answer: Prepare a hypodermic, please, Miss Price.

question: Now, Mr. Kessler, try not to excite yourself. Everything has been arranged. I shall come back to check on your progress and send a report to your parents. The police have requested to interview you and I have given them permission to do so.
answer: Thank you very much, Mr. Collins. He'll rest now and I'm sure everything will be fine once he's adjusted. He's had quite a shock.

question: How long have I been here?

question: Two weeks?

question: Lunatic?

question: I'm afraid you have to eat something.

question: You put me in an awkward position, Mr. Kessler.

question: Well, you're to take these after you've eaten. Now what kind of nurse would I be if I failed in so simple a task as giving out some pills?
answer: Leave the pills. I'll take them later.

question: Sorry.

question: Call me Alex.

question: Shall I be forced to feed you, Mr. Kessler?

question: Shall I be forced to feed you, David?

question: Right. Let's try a little harder, shall we?

question: You've never had bad dreams before?

question: Did you get a good look at the man who attacked you?

question: Yes.

question: Do you like it?

question: My best friend. My very best friend.

question: Yes, go on.

question: Will you think about it?

question: Now I'm embarrassed.

question: Where were we in the book?

question: Get the fuck out of here, Jack.

question: Rudy Levine the shmuck?

question: I'm going completely crazy.

question: What?!

question: Warn me? Will you get out of here, you meat loaf?

question: If you love me so much, Jack, you'll realize how disconcerting it is to share one's breakfast with the living dead!

question: I'm not listening!

question: Shut up, you zombie!

question: Will you be quiet?!

question: What?!

question: What are you talking about? I won't accept this! Get out! God damit!

question: Stop it, Jack.

question: Jack, please go away. Please go away.

question: Nurse! Oh God! Alex!

question: Yes.

question: No. He knows no one in London, besides me. I shouldn't have left him alone. Surely you're not suggesting....

question: I worried about you. We didn't know where you were. Where did you get that coat? I'll get it. Hello?

question: He's here.

question: No, why?
answer: Is David acting strangely?

question: No, not really.
answer: Could you get here without any trouble?

question: Yes, I should think so.
answer: Right. Now listen carefully. I want you to bring David here. I want him in my care. I'll notify the police that we've found him. It is imperative that you bring him straight to the hospital. Do you understand?

question: Yes, Doctor.
answer: You're certain he's lucid? You won't need any help?

question: He's fine. We'll come right over.
answer: Shall I send a car?

question: No, a cab will be faster.
answer: I expect you shortly. Yes, Scotland Yard?

question: The next corner we can get a cab.
answer: I should be committed.

question: Dr. Hirsch will know what to do.
answer: I don't know why I feel so good. I haven't felt this good in a long time. My body feels alive, alert. I feel like an athlete.

question: Get in. Saint Martin's Hospital. I beg your pardon?
answer: What murders? Pull over.

question: But....
answer: Pull over. Pay the man.

question: David, wait! David, what are you doing?
answer: Six people mutilated? It had to be me, Alex.

question: David, stop!
answer: I am going to the cops. There's a full moon tonight. Jack was right. I....

question: Jack is dead!
answer: Jack is dead. Look, six people have been killed. I'm going to the police.

question: David, please be rational. Let's go to Dr. Hirsch.
answer: Rational!?! I'm a fucking werewolf, for Christ's sake! Officer, I killed those people last night.

question: I swear, I don't know this girl.
answer: All right, you two, move along.

question: Hey, you asshole! I want you to arrest me!
answer: There's no call for that kind of language.

question: Queen Elizabeth is a man! Prince Charles is a faggot! Winston Churchill was full of shit!
answer: Now see here young man.

question: Shakespeare was French! The Queen Mother sucks cocks in hell! Shit! Fuck! Piss!
answer: That's quite enough!

question: Hopeless. It's hopeless.
answer: David, let's go now.

question: Leave me alone, dammit! You people are crazy! I've got to get away from here! I've got to do something!
answer: David, don't lose control.

question: Control!?! What control!?! Get away from me! Leave me alone!
answer: David, wait!

question: Yes, operator. I'd like to call the United States and reverse the charges. David Kessler for anyone. Yes, I'll wait. Hello? Yes, area code 315/472-3402. Thank you. Hello? Rachel? Just say yes, you'll accept the charges. Just say yes, Rachel. Is Mom or Dad home? Where are they? Where's Max? You're all alone? Mom and Dad wouldn't leave me alone when I was ten. No, not ten and a half either. I'm still in London. I'm all better. Look, would you tell Mom and Dad that I love them? I don't care, Rachel, just do it for me. Okay? Good. And, Rachel, don't fight with Max. Well, try. Look, kid, please don't forget to tell Mom and Dad I love them. I love Max and you, too. Well, I do. No, I'm not being weird, you little creep. You promise? Okay. Be a good girl. I love you. Bye. Will you take a traveler's check? Keep the change. Hi, Jack.
answer: Hi, David.

question: What can I say, Jack?
answer: You don't have to say anything.

question: Aren't you going to say, `I told you so'?
answer: If I was still alive, I probably would.

question: You look awful.
answer: Thank you.

question: I didn't mean it. I don't know what I'm saying. I'm not even sure it was me who killed those people. I don't remember doing it.
answer: What about the zoo?

question: Well, even if I'm not the wolfman, I am crazy enough to do something like that. I mean, here I sit in Leicester Square talking to a corpse. I'm glad to see you, Jack.
answer: I want you to meet some people. David Kessler, this is Gerald Bringsly.

question: Hello.
answer: Gerald is the man you murdered in the subway. We thought it best you didn't see him as he's a fresh kill and still pretty messy.

question: Yes, I do look most unpleasant.
answer: Why are you doing this to me, Jack?

question: This isn't Mr. Goodman's idea. He is your good friend, whereas I am a victim of your carnivorous lunar activities.
answer: Mr. Bringsly, I'm sorry. I have absolutely no idea what to say to you.
